reviewText:
tl;dr Yes, but with a warning below.

Age of Wonders, despite the age, is still a worthwhile game. It can appear deceptively simple at first, but as you begin to chip away at the abilities and magic system, you realise just how important deeper knowledge of the game mechanics can be.

A lot of the game has been covered by other reviewers. Essentially: turn based fantasy strategy game with empire management. Unlike the sequels - and many other games of its type - in Age of Wonders if your leader dies, you lose the game. This adds an extra layer of risk - your leader is powerful and can take down many basic units, but one wrong move and the game's over. It can sound cheap, but it really puts the stress on in major battles, something other strategy games miss out on. There is an option to remove this for the skirmishes, if you're not keen on it.

THE WARNING: this game, as it sits on Steam, is faulty. It crashes a lot - A LOT. Some people are fine, but looking at the reviews and the forums, it's wide spread enough for it to be an issue. You can fix this with a Hex editor. Now, I know some basic fixes are acceptable, but having to use a hex editor to fix the game is not. I imagine a lot of people out there don't know what a hex editor is, or how to even use one. Furthermore, I don't see any reason why this can't be done on the developers end - it took me two minutes, and would save everyone else a lot of headache.

Anyway, if you know what you're doing, this thread has the instructions: http://steamcommunity.com/app/61500/discussions/0/864973123853580717/

I very nearly put this as a thumbs down, but the cheap price, brilliant gameplay, and the fact that a fix is available - courtesy of the fan base (which, by the way, provide more maps and content than you'll ever manage to get through), I really can't bring myself to do it.

Thumbs up, only just, though.

But the gameplay overall was fun. Leveling up your heroes, selecting their new skills and equipping them with loot from the dungeons and haunted ruins you occasionally encounter is what made me love this game all those years ago. And it's still great.

This game is not for everyone, I know, and it might be an acquired taste. But I immensely enjoyed playing through it once more.

reviewText:
This is one of those games that I find myself coming back to again and again. I've played the sequels, but none of them can quite recreate the magic (no pun intended) of this classic. Everything from the fairly antiquated, yet still crisp and detailed graphics through the many tactical subtleties of combat which few later games have explored equally, to the absolutely brilliant and very loveable soundtrack. There is no reason why any fan of strategy, RPG and/or fantasy shouldn't have this game in his/her collection.

The probably most annoying flaw of the game, is the relatively small number of maps to play, and with no random map generator, you will play through the entire game quite fast. Luckily, there are still fans making and posting maps for everyone to download and rate. And of course, there is included with the game a super simple and intuitive map generator with all the tools you need to make whatever you like.

What I love most with this game is the rock solid gameplay, the timeless-without-being-boring take on fantasy races and themes, as well as the amount of units and options avaliable to you, combined with all the little details such as bloody, beaten corpses littering the battlefield and fields disappearing outside a city under siege. It makes for a game where you can instantly tell the team behind it has put their minds and souls into its creation. An attribute few games possess these days.

The game plays like Heroes of Might and Magic 4 which you can't buy on Steam.  They only let you get 3, 5, and 6 for whatever reason.

Still, the economy is very basic.  The campaign is very weird.  The AI suffers from either having an abundance of spammed units, or having a large economy that lets it spawn more spams.  I don't know why people think it adapts to upgraded tactics at all.  The game seems to succumb very easily to upgraded spells and units unless it just has a ton of units or premade units to counter with.   Often, the easy way to win is just raze a ton of enemy controlled cities so they can't spawn spams anymore since they don't have cities to build with or afford upkeep.  Thankfully, despite the morale system, there's also a race system.  That means the enemy will usually contain races that you don't contain, so when you raze their cities, it doesn't impact your own troops' morale.

I basically just played this game like Atilla the Hun, and it never really got challenging.  The only times you don't raze cities is if the computer was dumb enough to not conquer them in the first place.  Then, you just amass troops, and rush the enemy capital.   There's no need to bother with attacking independents if they just slow you down after you accepted the independents you're compatible with.

Honestly, Battle of Wesnoth is better... and it's free.

reviewText:
I have nearly 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews.

One Hour Reviews - Game 3
Age of Wonders
Purchase Date: 5/22/2014

I'd never played any of the Age of Wonders series.  This one I picked up as part of a Humble Bundle last year.    Humble is one of the reasons I ended up with as many games as I have, as they are a great excuse to donate a few dollars to a good cause and pick up a bundle of games while you are at it.  I get a lot of of games I wouldn't otherwise try this way.

As soon as I got into the game, I was immediately reminded of Heroes of Might and Magic.  Anyone who has ever played any of those games will be familar here.  I saw a lot of the same concepts here, with an emphasis on tactical turn based combat, along with exploration and town management.

Even though it's an older game, it ran absolutely fine on my system, and I could run at my native 1920x1080 resolution.  The text is a little small to read at that resolution, but otherwise I had no issues.    I had recently played Age of Empires II, and like that game, I found myself wanting to use the scrollwheel on my mouse to zoom in and out of the map, forgetting that scrollwheels weren't used in games back then.  Graphically speaking, the maps looked good, but I wasn't as impressed with the units, particularly the animation.

I started by going through the tutorial, which is pretty basic.  It covers the basics of getting around and how to issue commands to your party, but when it comes to actual strategy you are on your own.  It doesn't give you any sense for what you are about to get yourself into.  And I say this because this is not an easy game for someone just starting out.  In fact, I actually managed to die during the tutorial and had to start over.  It was my own fault, I sent my party leader to the front lines and he got himself killed, which immediately ended the game.

Once you finish the campaign, Age of Wonders offers you a campaign mode, which you can play from one of 2 sides, either the elves or the goblins.  The game also comes with a number of scenarios that you can play as well.  Since this is only an hour review, I did not look at any of the multiplayer, but I did find it interesting that the game has a play by email option.  I'm not used to seeing that in a lot of games.

I played a quick game though each side of the campaign.  I say quick game because Age of Wonders is not a kind game, and you can get yourself killed very quickly.  I did a little better when I played a scenario, but even then it wasn't terribly long before I was wiped out.  This is a game that expects you to learn from your mistakes, like any strategy game.

Ultimately I don't think this is really a game for me.    I didn't really see anything about this game to make it stand out.   Playing this just made me think back to playing the old Heroes of Might and Magic games.

Overall Recommendation:  Pass

I know I dont have many hours of play on this game and I dont usually review games if I have not played them for long but I have played AoW it when it first came out in 1999 and many years afterwards until my copy was lost. I think it's safe for me to review this version.

There is a bug that causes the game to freeze every 40 turns but frequent saving at the start of your turns makes this a minor issue. Simply restart your game and you're set. With that addressed this steam version is worth your money if multi unit turn-based strategy is your thing. You can find items in dungeons, caves, and castle ruins and level your heroes. Upon leveling you can pick new talents making this game rather customizable. You can play up to 12 different racial leaders in an effort to conquer the map. Each race is uniquely different than the others. You simply recruit your army through the cities you capture and upgrade the cities for more capable units. Great fun with friends either pvp or coop. The computer players have several difficulty settings. I cannot begin to tell you how much time I've spent playing this game. It has a high level of replay value due to the number of maps available. And I forgot to tell you that you can MAKE your own maps. Also there are a few fan-based sites that are STILL making downloadable maps. After 15 years fans are still releasing maps for this game.

Anyhow it's worth the five bucks. Also a caution: It can really suck you in and soak up your time. I catch myself saying 'just one more turn. Just one more battle. One more dungeon.' ... I said that an hour ago. Have Fun!
